chapter.title: Keystone
chapter.para: The simplest way to use Openstack API samples is to run on the same machine where openstack is installed.

section.title: List Roles
section.para: In this sample we will query Keystone to get list of Roles for a tenant.

listitem.programlisting: import keystoneclient.v2_0.client as ksclient from credentials import get_credentials from credentials import get_credentials_tenant

listitem.para: We will populate a dictionary and retrieve it using get_credentials() method.
Instantiate the client object keystone using the credentials dictionary object
Get List of Roles for each tenant
listitem.programlisting: keystone_tenant = ksclient.Client(**credentials_tenant) roles = keystone_tenant.roles.list() for r in roles: print r

section.programlisting:
import keystoneclient.v2_0.client as ksclient from credentials import get_credentials from credentials import get_credentials_tenant
credentials = get_credentials() try: keystone = ksclient.Client(**credentials) tenants_list = keystone.tenants.list() for t in tenants_list: print t.name credentials_tenant = get_credentials_tenant(t.name) try: keystone_tenant = ksclient.Client(**credentials_tenant) roles = keystone_tenant.roles.list() for r in roles: print r except Exception as inst: print 'Exception %s' % inst break finally: print "Execution Completed."

section.title: Create Role
section.para: The following program creates a role.
section.programlisting:
import keystoneclient.v2_0.client as ksclient from credentials import get_credentials
credentials = get_credentials() try: keystone = ksclient.Client(**credentials) print keystone.auth_url #Looks like a potential bug if keystone.auth_url != keystone.management_url: keystone.management_url = keystone.auth_url
role_name = "role1" role_exists = False roles = keystone.roles.list() for r in roles: if r.name == role_name: role_exists = True
if role_exists: print "%s already exists" % role_name
else: user_role = keystone.roles.create(role_name) print "Created role %s" % role_name finally: print "Execution Completed."

section.title: Create Tenant
section.para: The following program creates a tenant
section.programlisting:
import keystoneclient.v2_0.client as ksclient from credentials import get_credentials
credentials = get_credentials() try: keystone = ksclient.Client(**credentials) print keystone.auth_url #Looks like a potential bug #if keystone.auth_url != keystone.management_url: # keystone.management_url = keystone.auth_url tenant_name = 'user3-project' tenant_exists = False
tenants_list = keystone.tenants.list() for t in tenants_list: if t.name == tenant_name: tenant_exists = True if tenant_exists : print 'Tenant %s exists.' % tenant_name else: print 'Creating tenant %s ' % tenant_name req_body = { "tenant": { "name": tenant_name, "description": "Tenant user3-project", "enabled": True, "extravalue01": "metadata01", }, } tenant = keystone.tenants.create( req_body['tenant']['name'], req_body['tenant']['description'], req_body['tenant']['enabled'] ) print tenant
finally: print "Execution Completed."

section.title: List Users
section.para: The following program lists the users
section.programlisting:
import keystoneclient.v2_0.client as ksclient from credentials import get_credentials
credentials = get_credentials() try: keystone = ksclient.Client(**credentials) print keystone.auth_url
users_list = keystone.users.list() for u in users_list: print u
finally: print "Execution Completed."

section.title: Create User
section.para: The following program creates a user
